document.text: Yonr correspondent met a gentle-1 man yesterday who gives the follow- ing account of a most Singular evi-  deuce of intelligence on the part of  a horse belonging to K. L. Moore, of  this parish. The horses name is Dixie, and Moore raised him from a colt and is much attached to the animal. During the spring of 1894, Dixies knee was hurt while em ployed in repairing levees, and for some weeks thereafter he was not able to work at all and was allowed j to run loose in the pasture and about the place. One morning, when the hands were all in the fields at work and Moore himself was riding after them, they heard a violent ringing of the big plantation bell back at the house. Thinking something dreadful had happened to his wife or children, perhaps, Moore pout spurrs to his horse aud, calling to the hands to follow, galloped np to the house. When he got there he found Mrs. Moore and the children safe and sound aud very much amused at old Dixie,who bud managed to open the yard gate and was pulling on the bell-rope like a crazy thing. All their efforts to drive the horse away had been in vain he only continued to ring the bell more loudly. Moore began to suspect that Dixie might know what he was about after all, and went out to investigate. When the horse saw his master he let go the bell-rope and ran off to ward the pasture, looking back and tossing his head at every step, as if to say, Come on 1 Moore soon saw that something unusual had occurred and followed after Dixie as fast as he could. The horse made straight for the levee at the lower end of the pasture and stopped short under a _ A COllUUWWU ViCC When Moore came up, what was his astonishment to see a little break in the levee,with the water trickling through. Quickly summoning the hands the breach was soon healed. Bnt for Dixies timely . warning, however, the levee would have gone and the whole place wonld have been overflowed.

document.text: Williamsburg.- Virginias Fourth Estate celebrates 715 years of or ganization when the Virginia Press Association holds its Diamond An niversary Convention here Thurs- day, Friday and Saturday, Ju ly 18, 19-20. More than 300 Virginia newspapermen and women, their families and invited guests will participate in the gathering. Highlight of the convention will be the Parks-Franklin memorial ob servance in tribute to Virginias colonial printer and Americas first Public Printer. Working in coopera tion with the Colleg of William and Mary and the Virginia 350th Anniversary Celebration, the V . P. A . will hold a dinner on Ju ly 19, following which wili be the presen tation of an award to the Ameri can adjudged the outstanding champion of freedom of informa tion and the never-ending battle for the peoples right to know. Nominations for the recipient of the award have been received from throughout the United States. Pre sentation will be held in Phi Beta Kappa hall. The recipient, whose name has not been disclosed, will be present ed a solid silver miniature of n_ colonial press. The press, fashioned of five .pounds ocf silver, was de signed and executed by William de- Mjaltte, Colonial Williamsburg silver smith who made the Freedom Bell presented to Sir Winston Churchill T8 months ago in recognition of his championship of freedom. Cost of the silver press minia ture was borne by most of the daily and weekly newspapers in Virginia. Speaker at the dinner will be Raymond Blattenberger, United States public printer and head of the government printing office in Washington, and Don Whitehead, chief of the Washington Bureau of the Nhw York Herald Tribune, and former Associated Press corespon dent who won two Pulitzer prizes for distinguished reporting. Miss Marguerite Osborne, Edi tor of The -Virginia Gazette, is chairman of the V . P. A . Awards Committee, Ralph K . T . Larson, managing editor of the Norfolk Virginian-Pilot and a member of the award committee, will preside at the dinner. The invocation will be given by the Rev. Cotes worth Lewis, rector of old Bruton Parish Church in Williamsburg. Alvin D. Chandler, president of the College of William and Mary, will deliver the address of welcome.

document.text: What Alexander and Lilbourne Patteson had in mind was to build up a great stage coach business. They never dreamed that the Tavern they built at Clover Hill, in 1819, would become the museum of relics of a great peace for a nation re united after four years of bitter internacine war. Clover Hill Tavern is the oldest building at the Appomattox Court House National Military Park. It has just been restored and houses the National Park Service Museum . . . a museum now displaying as a late addition the famous Guillaume paint ing of the Surrender of Gen. Robert E. Lee to Gen. U. S. Grant, April 7, 1865. Another new feature is an electric map, showing just where the great events of history occured here. Two brothers, Alexander and Lil bourne Patteson, opened a stage coach line from Lynchburg to Rich mond in 1811. At that time the im mediate area at what is now Old Appomattox Court House was a part of Prince Edward County, Appomat tox County not having been estab lished until 1845. In 1814 the Pat teson brothers purchased 206 acres laying near the north branch of the Appomattox River from one John B. Sadler. The land was valued at 157.89. In 1819 they built the Clover Hill Tavern, and the property zoomed to a value of 7,890. There is quite a story about these Patteson -brothers. A 208 page In formal History of the Virginia-Ken- tucky Pattesong in Illinois, Their Forbears and Their Kin by Ethel Marion Smith, traces the Patteson ancestry back to 1680. The first Pat teson entry in St. Peters Parish Reg ister in Eastern Virginia, shows that one Thomas Patteson came over from England in 1680 and settled on what is known as Roxbury Plan tation. Thomas Patteson had five sons Thomas, Edward, David, Alex ander and Geofrge, The next name to look for was Obfcdiah Patteson, who the St. Peters Parish Register says was born in 1750. His second son was named Littleberry . . . and father and son, Obediah and Little- berry took up land patents in this section in 1782. Records exist that show! that Obediah Patteson paid taxes on 800 acres of land in Camp bell County from 1782 through 1791. Littleberry Patteson was born in New Kent County in February, 1754, married in 1782 and died June 23, 1827. He fought in the Revo lutionary War. He is known to have paid taxes on land in Buckingham County from 1793 to 1814. He married Matilda Smith. Lilbourne and Alexander, build ers of Clover Hill Tavern, were sons of Littleberry Patteson. They owned Clover Hill Plantation, under a deed dated November 25, 1814. Alexander Patteson died in 1836, and his fam ily moved to Kentucky. Family rec ords show that the family was prom- ient. David Patteson of Chesterfield, Jonathan of Lunenburg, and Charles of Buckingham represented their re spective counties in the Virginia Convention of 1788 to ratify the United States Constitution. A stage coach line was a great thing 150 years ago. Clover Hill Tavern was a grand conception at a time when Americans were fan ning out from the Atlantic Coast and moving Westward. The Clover Hill Tavern remained in the hands of the Patteson family until Aug ust 8, 1839, when it passed to John Raine. It was transferred to Hugh Raine in 1842 for the sum of 3,- 200, and again passed to Samuel McDearmon in 1845. McDearmon, a great leader in the early growth of this section and one of the top citizens of his time, added many outbuildings and improvements to the Tavern. However, he sold the property to Samuel Glover in 1854. The foundation lines of this store are today readily apparent as a de pression in the ground between the Tavern and the Ferguson home, re cently used as Park Service office. About the year 1859, Glover transferred his holdings to Wilson Hix. The holdings at that time con sisted of lots 16 and 17 in the vil lage of Appomattox Court House and contained the Tavern and its outbuildings. Hix operated the prop erty as a hotel all through the Civil War period. It was yvritten up in the New York Hearld in April, 1865. It was referred to as Glenns Hotel and was used as the office of the paroling officer. Gen. Sharpe. In 1880, it was transferred from the estate of Wilson Hix to Edward G. Hix and included lots 11, 17, 18 and part of lot 16 in the village. The ownership continued to change hands until finally resting in the Continued on Page Eight

Now the people of the district are unable to bear the burden of pay ing even a penny for a meal and are compelled to fail back on charity. In Wales and Scotland and in the Industrial districts of England relief works have been started and soup Kitchens established. There is scarce ly a mining village in Scotland where the children are not being fed by the public authorities. In the English coal fields the people are better off, as the trades union funds are richer and will last much longer. It Is estimated that the miners thus far have lost in wages 26,408,850, be sides the depletion of the union funds.

It has been a privilege for you men and women to live in this blessed atmosphere, IMS a great privilege to feel that mystic  union, that spiritual relationship be- tween those on earth and those in I that Paradise where Christ shall set I up His kingdom, and His children will be with Him. And I want to maln- 1 tain the prestige of this pulpit. You i say that is a difficult thing to do. It j is not difficult, If I obtain the prayers and sympathy of those who worship here. Christs process Is a heavenly process, and so the process of reju venation is a heavenly process. I cannot explain to you the coming to gether of the people of a congrega tion. I cannot explain to you how in the taking of this blessed sacrament of the body and blood of Jesus Christ, God Invested the blessed recipient with heavenly grace. I cannot ex plain to you when you are asking a special blessing on the rector who is ministering to you day after day. That Is a spiritit may seem old- fashioned, but that is a spirit of aban don which I possess when it comes to the things pertaining to God. Notnr Ing is paradoxical, nothing Is Incom prehensible to me in the scheme of God. I take the Bible from lid to lid. I take the miracles set forth Ini tne Bible without question. I accept them, in the fulness of my heart, becauf God is not God unless He puts Into these works His own power, His own spirit. His own love. I have seen men sent from tne transcendent heights of splendid man hood down to the dismal depths of degradation. I have seen a lace marred with the marks of sin, and the body heavy with the weight of sin. And I have seen this same Individual rejuvenated with the spirit of God, It Is transm utation of the elements on the individual. It is bringing the whole man into play, according to- Gods direction. I believe that to-day the church- stands forth more glorious than It has ever stood, because the Spirit has been operating In its own way In the. hearts of men. The Spirit now is op erating more than It has since the

document.text: une Tramp. The curse of the man who will not work has always been with us. In Henry VIIIs reign he was not allowed to beg the bread that belonged to hon- ester folk, for a statute was made by which the old and impotent were granted licenses to beg, and anyone found begging without one was sound ly flogged and sent home to his own parish. In this way as many as a hun dred in one day, in Elizabeths time, were sent back to the land. The begging license seems to work well enough abroad, where the row of authorized beggars is a familiar sight outside every church, and where the halt and maimed are seldom seen any where else. The rise of the vagrant in this country no doubt took place after the destruction of the monaster ies, and before any other relief-giving body took their place. Yet, after the queens magnificent gift we can still say with the monk of medieval times, The friendship of the poor makes us the friends of kings.London Chronicle.

document.text: U D C Meeting The Appomattox Chapter of the United Daughters of the Confederacy met on Thursday, April 15, at 730 p.m. at Farmers National Bank, T ri-. angle Plaza Branch. There were 17 members ip attendance. Pledges to the United States Flag and salutes of the Virginia Flag and the Confederate Flag were led by toe president, Mrs. Lena Eversole. The ritual was read by Mrs. Frances Harvey. Also the Confederate Prayer by Mrs. Harvey. Mrs. Frances Harvey, secre tary, read the minutes of the last meeting which were approved. Mrs. Louise Plunkett gave a report on the memorial fund. Members voted. to donate 10.00 to the Skip Island Memorial Fund, ft  t Mrs. Eversole announced that the 3rd District Confer ence will meet on May 22 at 10 a.m. at the Parish House of the Trinity Episcopal Church, Main St., South Boston Va. Mrs. ucille Fertoll, histo Ian, gaVq an interesting talk on EdmundRuffins. Mrs. C. A. Moore led the group in singing southern songs, closing with Blest Be the Tie That Binds. Delicious refreshments were served by the hostesses Mrs. Wiley Moore,  Mrs. Alton Moore, Mrs. Claude A. Moore, Mrs. H. L. Wilkerson, Mrs. E. J. Hillsman and Mrs. B. Curray Harvey. The May meeting will meet on May 20 at 6 p.m. in the home of Mrs, Helen Gunter for a covered dish supper. Mrs. Tilden Lee, U.D.C Publicity

document.text: U . S. Board Ends Dispute Over Naming of Island A 160-year dispute over the correct name of the island on which the Statue of Liberty stands ended with the announcement by the United States board of geographical names that its correct name is Bedlots island. The New York harbor island has, been called Bedlow island, Red. loe island and Bedloes island since it was owned by Isaac Bedloe between 1667 and 1672. f The geographical names board of the interior department decides dis putes over names and selects-hantos for places heretofore unnamed. Under Secretary Ickes, the an nouncement on the boards work stated, the policy of the board has been to avoid officially naming places and objects after living per sons so that the christening function cannot be used for political - pur poses. Among the 398 decisions handed down in the last year was one con cerning a bayou in Louisiana. The stream, located in Terrebonne parish, should be called Bayou Col- yell, the board decided. It teiM not be called Bayou Qo-tP-HeU,

document.text: Two Minnesota Families Have Marriage Monopoly MINNEOTA, MINN.St. Ed wards Catholic parish has set a matrimonial record. Five children of Mr. and Mrs. Will Gossen have married five children of Mr. and Mrs. Nick Janssen in five years. And theres still time to make the record better. Mr. and Mrs. Gossen, farm ers five miles northeast of here, have 14 children. Mr. and Mrs. Janssen, who retired from their farm here and moved to town, have 12 children. Father Philip Casey has per formed all five marriages and says hed like to officiate at more.

document.text: tifle thought. The man they described  as the simple parish priest was not moved by the onslaught. He took j the position that the new sect i should not be tolerated. He realized that prominent men in his own fold were among the leaders, and some of them, when brought face to face with the ultimatum of Pius X.. recanted, while others left the church. The effect of this encyclical has been felt in all Europe and in the United States. It came like a bomb. On becoming supreme pontiff there j was of course some real curiosity shown as to the attitude of Pius X. in his relations with the Quirinal. it was flgured in some quarters that the new pontiff was kindly disposed to ward the Italian government, and that  as a result the breach which was i made in the Porta Pia and by which was effected the overthrow of the temporal power of the Pope back in  1870 would be filled in and all differ ences between the Vatican and Quiri nal settled amicably, but Pius X. fol lowed the exampU et by Pio Nono and Leo XIII. He refused to recognize the law of guarantees which had been passed by the Senate and chamber of the Italian Parliament on May 13, 1871, that con cerned the prerogatives of the Holy See and the relations between church and state in the kingdom of Italy. Among the stipulations were The Popes person to be sacred and in- 1 violable, and he be treated with royal honors and that he be given an an nual endowment of 3,225,000 lire, or 022,425, to cover all the needs of the Holy See. This law was not recog nized by Pio Nono or by Leo XIII., and the endowment has been accumu lating annually, it Is said, since the law was passed. Pius X. did not draw on the funds, and he did not take advantage of the assurances of military protection. He shut himself up in the Vatican after the example of his two predecessors and remained a voluntary prisoner. The Pope In 1906 sent a pastoral , letter to the Catholic clergy and laity of certain Roman churches ex- ! isting In Russia, warning them against j countenancing in any way the out-  rages on. the Jews. At that time there was some talk as to why the Pope 1 interested himself thus far in the i Jews. But It was soon explained that I the holy father numbered among his j stanch friends some of the wealthiest

document.text: There was a time in the history of Farmville when Lunenburg was one of its best pattens and while the trade from that grand old coun ty, generally called the Free State, has fallen off it is still no mean contributor to our success as a town and we are watching Lunen burg grow with genuine inti rest. The building of the Tidewater railroa 1 through that country has given a new life-thrill to it. Real estate values have greatly increased and the timber interests of the county are attracting wide spread attention. Victoria, the terminous of a division of the road, is build ing rapidly and promises to be a town of considerable size and im portance. There is no good that can come to Lunenburg that Farm ville will not rejoice in. There 117 students at Hampden Sidney this session as against 72 two years ago and 82 last year. The number cf new students is 79 as against 22 two years ago and 43 last year. Of the whole numbi r enrolo 1 this year Virginia sends 82 West Virginia 2, Tennessee New Jersey, 2, while Florida, Ill inois, Maryland, Mississippi and North Carolina send one each, and Japan sends one. This is dr,ing well and Richmond should let well enough alona. A library for Farmville may be reckoned among the assured facts. The mothers of our town are be hind the movement and that means it must go. At a recent public meeting which was held in the in terest of the project representative business men made enthusiastic speeches in its. advocacy and noth ing remains but to get the books and go to reading. McCauly says, reading makes a full man so that we will have two pl aces at which our people may get fu ll li brary and dispensary. The Normal girls not only en joy the splendid faculty of 26 of gifted men and women. Mrs. Brooks, the accomplished lady mat ron, who has been kept from the school for sometime, is on duty again. The Episcopalians o 1 our town are still without a rector, though the pulpit of the church has been well filled of late. Mr. Garnett, our new postmaster begins to look very much at home in the new position. With  pleas ant duties to perform and a 2000 salary to draw with unvarying reg ularity most of us would feel com fortable in the cozy official nest. With one exception, that of star route mail carriers, Uncle Sam is a good pay master. The old gentle man is especially kind in his deal ings with his day laborers, who work only 8 hours and have 16 for play and sleep. I have always thought that was ideal division of the day. Farmers who rise at 3 a m and retire at 8 p m wont agree with me however. The health of Mrs. Tom Clark is far from good, and she may go to a sanitarium near Asheville, N. C. for treatment. Ur. J, W. Gills has elaborately furnished offices over the store room of Messrs. Verser  Son. He is gaining in popular favor day by day, and is not only learned in his profession but knows how to meet with the people. A cheerful, com panionable, family physician is better than physic. Mr. Vernon Paulette went west not in search of a wife, but he found one and telegraphed the fact to his Farmville friends. A happy greeting awaits them on their ecin- ing to the old home, and the old friends. Our merchants and milliners are stocked up for spring and summer and stand waiting for customers. Mrs. R. S. Paulette and sister, Mrs. Bettie Venable, of Hampden Sidney, have been visiting in Wash- ngtrn and Baltimore. Mrs. Dr. Messenger is on a visit to home folks in Iowa. Mrs. Wallace Burnette, of Wash ington, vho has been with us re gaining her strength after practical illness, will return to her home ou the 1st of April. Prospective sweet girl graduates are already excited over diplomas, flowerB, addresses, white dresses and farewells. May their brightest hopes be all realize l. And yet tha broader field before them is not a flower-garden but a work-field Bishop Tucker paid his first visit to this parish recently and has left behind him a pleasant memory. I wonder that Farmville ever abandoned holding her annualFairs

It is not too  r fay that if it had not beer for him, there never would have been any Christianity, as a world- religion It would have died as Jewish sect. .. What the history of the world would have been in that rase God only knows. But al- Stfh our so-called Christian era is still not exactly Chris tian, it Is vastly different from what it would have been II Christianity had been no more say than Essenism, a word you would have to look up in the enclycopedia, an antique and forgotten sect. To many un-named Christians, but to Paul more than any other one person, we owe the fact that ours is a religion with a world-outlook.

document.text: The We-Feeling G OD INVENTED the family that is what is meant by calling it a  divine institution of Gods plan foi dren that he learn how to live, not in a lonely cell by himself, not as a lonely wolf fighting against a l l comers, but as a member of a famiiy. The f a m i l y is enormously impor tant in many ways. There is room to speak of only one of them. Students of personality have found a new but simple name for something that every one ought to have, but not every one does have it is called the  we-feeling. The lone-wolf type of person never really thinks we. His mind divides the world into two armed camps on the one side is I and on the other side is every one else. He goes through life assuming that nobody is for him, nobody is with him, and he in turn is for no body and with nobody. His  hand is against every man, as the Bible says. Even if he teams up with others for a while, he will double- cross them if he thinks he will make something out of it. He is your typical criminal, anti-social as teachers and sociologists call him.    What It Means to Grow Up fH IL D R E N usually begin l i f e  without m u c h , we-feeling, if any. They dont naturally share their toys or their dinners or any thing else. They grab all they can and they dont like to be grabbed from. The process of growing up really growing up, not merely get ting older and biggeris a process ef developing a healthy we-feeling. Nearly every one develops this to some extent, of course but when some people say  we they dont mean very many. We have all heard of the man who prayed Lord, bless me and my wife, my son John and his wife. Us four, no more. Amen! He doesnt make a very good citizen. But as the  we -circle grows wider and wider we get a more and more publie-spirited and service- minded citizen, till at the high point of the we-feeling we see a man like St. Paul who calls himself a debtor to all men, or like John Wesley who said, The world is my parish, or a modern inter national citizen and statesman such as John R. Mott.

document.text: The Seventy-Seventh An nual Convention, Virginia Div ision of the United Daughters of the Confederacy was held in Williamsburg, Virginia, on October 3rd, and October 4th, at the Williamsburg colony Motor Inn. A Memorial Service was held in the Bruton Parish Episcopal Church honoring the deceased members of the entire Virginia Division. The total deceased members were 105, and as each name of the deceased member was called a white carnation was placed on a green wreath which was accepted by Mrs. Russell B. Frost, President of the Vir ginia Division, and was placed at the Confederate Monument in the church yard. Tuesday was Historical night and a Grand March honored the Virginia Division and General Officers. Wednesday was Chapter Presidents night, beginning with the Grand March of Presidents of all Chapters, at which time the Historians and Recorders of the Crosses of each Chapter were also recognized. The Appomattox Chapter was awarded two prizes. One, a 5.00 prize, was awarded the local Chapter for enrolling the second largest number of new members in the Virginia Div ision. document.text: The rural ministers summer school, one of the oldest continuous leadership training programs con ducted by the VPI Agricultural Ex tension Service, will be held at VPI July 4-8. Co-sponsor of the program, which is entering its second quarter cen tury this year, is the Rura Church Department of the Virginia Council of Churches. Dr. D. R. Fessler, rural sociologist at VPI, say3 the faculty for the 1955 school is one of the most not able in recent years. The principal morning speaker will be Dr. Samuel Blizzard of Pennsylvania State University. His series of four talks on the rural parish minister, will be the first major presentation of the findings of a study he conducted un der the auspices of the Russel Sage Foundation and the National Council of Churches. Dr. Harold E. Smith of Perdue University also will con duct a series of four morning talks on the rural church and the com munity. Discussion seminars will follow the morning lectures. Afternoons will be open for relaxation and re creation. Evening speakers will include Dr. L. George Nace, Perdue University, executive secretary of the Division of Home Missions of the National Council of Churches and Dr. Alfred P. Fernback, associate professor of foreign affairs, University of Vir ginia.

document.text: The First Presbyterian Chur ch of Sparta, Term., was the evening setting June 18 for the wedding of Miss Brenda Alberta Mann and Mr. Philan der Kelsey. The bride, given in marriage by her father, chose an elegant gown, of while peau de soie and alencon lace. The bodice was designed with a bibbed yoke of lace adorned with seed pearls. The wedding band collar and deep stenciled cuffs of bishop sleeves were eteched with scallops of lace. The semi-circu lar skirt bordered in matching lace cascaded into a chapel length train. document.text: The English Church Two Centuries Ago. If you were to ask any person specially interested in the Church of Englandnot necessarily a clergyman of that church which was the deadest and lowest and feeblest period of the churchs existence, he would without the least hesitation re ply that the reign of George n covered that period. It is certain that the churches were what is commonly called ngly, that is to say, they were built by Wren, I or were imitations of his style, and had nothing to do with Early English or Deco rated or even Perpendicular. Also, it is certain that the congregations sat in pews, each family - by itself that there were some few pews of greater dig nity than others, where sat my lord mayor, or the aldermen, or the sheriffs, or the masters of the city companies. It is also certain that all the churches had galleries, that the services were performed from a three decker? , that the sermon was preached in a black gown, and that the clergyman called himself a minister, and not a priest. All these forms are abomina tions to the latter half of the Nineteenth century. There were also pluralists the poor were left very much to themselves, and the parish was not worked according to modern ideas.W alter Besant in Har per

document.text: The Appomattox Chapter of the United Daughters of the Confederacy met in the home of Mrs. Hazel Lee Martin on Thursday, Feb. 21, at 12 noon for a covered dish luncheon. Mrs. Harriett Cunningham returned thanks for the food for the 19 members in attendance who gathererd around the dining room table for a most delightful meal.   Mrs. Martin, chapter presi dent, presided at .the meeting. ! The Pledge of Allegiance to the United States flag was led by Mrs. Helen Gunter. Mrs. Mary Sue Gordon led the salute t the Virginia flag, and fhe salute to the Confederate flag was led by Mrs. Gladys Jbhnson.  Mrs. Martin read the ritual and Mrs. Cunningham read the Confederate prayer. Mrs. Martin announced that the Third D istrict Spring Conference, Virginia Division, U.D.C. will meet with the Appomattox Chapter on Satur- cfey, April 12, at the Parish House at St. Annes Episcopal Church in Appomattox. Regist ration and a coffee hour will be ffom 915 to 10 a m.  Mrs. Lena Eversole read a fetter from Mrs. Lula Hunter Jones who was the first president of the Appomattox Chapter, U.D.C. when it was p-ganized on Aug. 22,1895. The fetter was written Sept. 30,  9 6 to Mrs. Eversoles grandmother, Mrs. Betty Sears Caldwell, and requested help in getting the chapter better organized and established. I Mrs. Harriett Cunningham presented an interesting prog ram on Major General Patrick Ronayne Cleburne. . J Born in Ireland, Cleburne S me to America at the age of after serving in the British Army. He settled in Arkansas, pas a fierce defender of states ights and loved this new country where he could earn the right to be heard, vote his beliefs and be able to buy land tp develop as he saw fit.  When war came, because of tis past training, he was made a Captain in the Yell Rifles. His Organization and training of his troops, his bravery and Ladership in battle brought Rim his appointment to brigadier general. 5 He was sent to Huntsville, Alabama, was at Murfreesboro,

document.text: The 25,000 issue of 4 per cent. Fred ericksburg .city bonds have all been taken by the National Bank of Fredericksburg. Giles Maddox, employed by the  tr- ginia Locust Pin Company, Front Royal, had three lingers almost severed from his left hand while running a lathe. Mr. J. W. Bitzer was elected Mayor of Leesburg by 17 majority over S. Carroll Chancellor, Joseph Wright and E. L. Pleasants. Elsie Perrow, the 8 -months-old clulu of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Perrow, of Lynch burg, was strangled at the home of her parents in a tragic manner. The lithe one was left on a bed by its mother while she was attending to her house hold duties. The child evidently rolled off the bed, and as she fell her dress caught in a projecting port. 1 of the springs, suspending h e r between the bed and the floor. When discovered the lit- tie girl was dead. The blow has pros trated Mrs. Perrow. This was her only- child. . , Mrs. Lucy Pearman, a young married woman of Richmond, lost her life as a result of an effort to kindle a fire in a cook stove with kerosene oil. _Mrs. Pearman occupied a flat at 415 North Twenty-second street. As she started to light the fire about 7 A. M. an explo sion occurred, setting her clothing on fire. Though she was dragged worn the building by a neighbor, Harry YVilson, who himself sustained painful injuries, the young woman died almost instantly. Mrs. Pearman was the wife of B. W. Pearman, a bridge builder in the employ of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad, who at the time was in Rocky Mount, N. C. .  Carelessly stepping m front of an en gine on the Richmond, Fredericksburg and Potomac Railroad, in Richmond, Ju nius Jones, a miller, 5  years old, was crushed to death. His widow and six children survive. Rev. Manson T. Dye, head of a set of religious enthusiasts of Danville, known locally as Holy Jumpers, was arraigned in the Mayors Court, charged with creating a disturbance. A number of citizens complained of boisterous con duct of Dye and his followers in the streets at night. The services consist mainly of screams and shouts and gym nastic performances. The Mayor did not impose a fine, but ordered modera tion. T Augustus Walker and two sons, Lester S. Walker and Holland Walker, who were charged with robbing a number of stores in Shenandoah county, were given preliminary hearings. Augustus Walker was fined 20 for receiving stolen goods. Lester Walker was sent to the grand jury, and Holland Waker, who is 13 years of age, was sent to the reformatory near Richmond. Mr. Grant Parish, real estate broker, of Washington, sold Paul Kcstcr s Woodlawn Mansion House property, about four miles back from Mount Ver non. It was originally a part of the lands of George Washington, who left that portion and built thereon for Nel lie Custis Lewis the present Woodlawn Mansion House. The mansion is brick, has about 22 rooms and is located on 1 commanding elevation. The price paid was 25,000 cash. The new owner is Miss Elizabeth M. Sharpe, o f Orange, N. J. It is believed that Mrs. Lucy APuck- ett, who was struck by a train near Lynchburg, was not killed by the train, but that she dropped dead of heart dis- ase On the track, otherwise she would have had ample time to have escaped being struck. Eye-witnesses declare she lay on the track when she was struck. The pilot picked her up and threw her at least 20 feet into the air, breaking al most every bone in her body. The fund for a Confederate monu ment at Bowling Green, Caroline county, has reached nearly i, 5  The com mittee is considering designs for the monument, and later will call a general meeting of veterans and citizens, when there will be speaking. A dinner and a band of music will also be features. It is expected that the cornerstone will be laid on that occasion. Ralph P. Gage, formerly of the law firm of Wolcott, Wolcott  Gage, en tered suit in the Court of Law and Chancery at Norfolk against Thomas H. Robbins, of Washington, claiming 10,- 000 for alleged defamation of character. A heavily loaded wagon of the Gentry dog and pony show, drawn by four horses, broke through a bridge at Grat- ton, killing one horse and injuring Chas. Cooper, of Columbus, Ohio, and Her- bert Braxton. The extensive plant of the .Beaver Creek Lumber Company, Davis, has closed down and several hundred men are out of employment. It is believed the shutdown will be of short duration. Ground was broken at Marshall Col lege, Huntington, by the senior class tor the new Marshall College building. The cornerstone was dedicated by Miss Fan nie Wysor, who broke a bottle of wine on i The commencement address was deivered by Rev. Dr. Charles W. Dab ney, of Cincinnati. Miss Fannie L. Harmon, of Monon- Kah, took a civil-service examination for the position of rural mail carrier. She is an accomplished horsewoman. The Bromall Iron and Steel Company at Belington, is making steady progress with the construction of the buildings for the extensive plant. Three weeks ago Policeman William H Wyatt, Jr., who became famous by closing single-handed all the gambling lens in Richmond, was given a fur lough and entered the race for the office sf high constable. Just six days before he primary election he and his wife are sick with what is supposed tg be typhoid fever.

document.text: that he possessed the three designat ed qualifications. He applied for the place, was accepted and installed, and, for a time, all went well with the pastor and liis flock. But this serenity was not destined to long duration. It was learned, in some way not explainednor is the ex planation materialthat Mr. Boyd had voted for Grover Cleveland in 1892. He had done this quietly, had uot preached politics during the 92 campaign, but suspicion was excited by something Mugwumpian in his appearance. An investigation was held and the startling truth came out. Of course there was trouble. Many of the young pastors parish ioners refused to contribute to his support, and others reproached him. Mr. Ephraim Morris, a woolen man ufacturer, is one of the principal financial pillars of this church, his contribution beiug one-third of the total annual expenses. Mr. Morris says of this matter I mistrusted from Mr. Boyds application that he was not a Re publican and cautioned the commit tee against hiring him, saying that I would not contribute to the support of a Democrat but they were all wise and had their way. I gave tbem fair warning and they must take the consequences. I went to Mr. Boyd and he acknwledged that he voted for Mr. Clevelaud. I am a woolen manufacturer. Democra cy is detrimental to my business,and I wouldnt hear the gospel preached by a Democrat any more than I would cut off my right hand. If they secure a Republican they can have my support otherwise theyll go without i t  There is nothing unlawful in the attitude of Mr. Morris. He has a right to put his money where he thinks it will do the most good, but is he not going too far in con cluding that Mr. Boyd is a Demo crat merely because he voted for Mr. Clevelaud iu 1892 ? Would it not be better to follow the example of ex-President Harrison, who has urged his neighbors to vote for a candidate for Mayor of Indianopolis who did just what the Rev. Mr. Boyd did in 1892 ? Mr. Harrison regards this bolter as a Republican in 1895, in spite of the slip three years ago. Mr. Harrison will go to the polls and cast his ballot for the man who scratched him and voted for his opponent. We think this is a good example, good politics, and good morals. These w avering breth ren in Vermont should turn their gaze westward and let it rest on the form of the ex-Presideut as he goes to the polls and votes for his former enemy.Washington Post.

document.text: TH E FIG H TING PASTOR. During the Civil war there were  a few fighting parsons and here comas an Espiscopal rector, who says I am a rector of a parish in the Protestant E p i s c o p a l church, and I am sure the clergy generally will gain more respect, win complete confi dence in their leadership and accomplish greater results in honorable field of endeavor when they cease to avail them selves of the privelege of ex emption and show a readiness to get on the common level with all men when occasion de mands a work inconspicuous and heroic. We admire the heroic spirit of the rector, but we still in sist that a man called of God to preach the Gospel has no time for anything else. The church is called the church militant and that means a fighting church but the war it should wage is against sin in all its forms and the weapons are spiritualthe Sword of the Spirit and the Word of God. Go with the soldier boys to the front, brother, ready to admin ister to soul wants, and, as far as you can, to bodily comfort.. Enter the trenches, if needs be not to shoot Germans, but at proper time and in the proper manner bid the soldiers to be as true to the Christ as they are to oountry. This one thing I do, and woe is me if I preach not the Gospel.

document.text: Tbe Earthly Paradise. In the days when William Morris ! sras regarded only as an apostle of  beauty there were people who  thought that if they had stuck a i Morris paper on their ______ ____ Morris chintz on their furniture, had, perhaps, subscribed to a Morris window in the parish church, they really were in the foremost ranks of culture. It was a comfortable thought, and, for families of even moderate means, the thing was so easy to do that the foremost ranks were for a time quite crowded, and became rather fashionable instead of s little ridiculous, - tbey were deemed at first. The outward sign is so readily identified with the spirit ual grace that to daub a wall over with beautiful patterns and to cover windows with hangings of gorgeous dye were reckoned quite important matters, lending to the inmates of the house an intellectual and moral j superiority that could be felt. By adding some Burne-Jones photo- j graphs, vellum-bound books, and  Liberty muslins, it seemed possible I to reach a kind of earthly paradise. ___  T ondon Nation.

document.text: T albot disgustedly relinquished Me golf, and in the Bbrary of the hall w rote the anonymous letter to the chief. Then, in Ms gray car, he setoff for the city to mail the letter. When he was in the car, the engine throbbing easily, Elinor ventured to put her hand on his arm. L ast night, she said rapidly, W al te r threatened ail,sorts of tM ngs that he would get the morning collection at Saint Judes, that he would kill Mr. W ard. I am frightened, Taille. Talbot patted her hand. We will get this fixed .up so it wont be necessary  and as for the other, you know W alter. H e w as mad with jealousy last night. T h ats all talk. On th at wild ride T albot had little tim e to think, but, such as they were, his thoughts were of Elinor and her caprice. Its the preacher, after all, he said to himself. Its enough to make old H ilary turn over. From th a t his mind wandered to W alter. He knew Huff, the violence of his temper, the madness of his passion for the girl. Talbot was uneasy. Elinor had an unexpected visitor th at afternoon. It was th e B ryant roman. White, but very dignified, Elinor cam e into th e drawing room. B ut Mrs. B ryant had not come about the pearL You m ust forgive a Sunday visit, she said. B ut I have taken Mr. Bry an t to the country dub, and I wanted so much to come to see you. Elinors color returned. It is very kind of you to cotne. Mrs. B ryants smalt, birdlike eyes darted over the room. The house was distinctly good form. Perhaps the girl m ight be an acquisition to the social life of the village. A fter all, religion was becoming very broad. Even the best people The country club, said Mrs. Bry an t aloud, is full of disagreeable memories to me ju st now. It was less than a week ago that I w as robbed. A h! said Elinor. Robbed! How interesting ! All my jewels, everything I pos sessed th at was really w orth while. B ut surely the police Mrs. B ryant flushed with anger. The police ! she said. It wouldnt surprise me a t all to discover that the police are In with the thieves. Look a t the condition of this country! It has been terror-ridden fo r the last two or .three years. You yourself are a victim. Your poor father ! Actually she had detested old Hilary. She sat forw ard on the edge of her chair and spoke with great unction. There is a band of organized, in telligent bandits working, in this neigh- borhood, Miss Kingston, a band of m ur derers. In these days of feminism, it wouldnt astonish me a t all to discover th at some woman Is a t the head of it. The tMngs th at have been planned have been so fiendishly clever ! Mrs. B ryant rose. It shows how demoralizing such things are, she said. I assure you th a t I never look a t a womans throat these days without expecting to see my pearl. From th at dangerous ground she stepped quickly to the burning of the parish house, wMch she believed was the work of m ilitant suffragettes. The dear rector is not a feminist, she said. His assistant, I fear, has a strong tendency ln th a t direction. But he .is a wonderful person, really. Ju st Imagine, seventy-eight thousand dol lars was collected in Saint Judes church tM s morning for rebuilding the parish house! She turned a t the doorway. TO BE CONTINUED. .
